Award.AwardTitle: CER: MyCS - Middle Years Computer Science

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Harvey Mudd College will adapt exemplary educational resources to create MyCS, a CS curriculum whose goal is to develop positive computational identities among middle-school students. A positive computational identity subsumes self-efficacy, enjoyment, and future engagement with creating computation. The project's approach existing pedagogical resources into three distinct MyCS variations. Inspired by UCLA's high-school course, Exploring Computer Science (ECS), the first variation broadly explores computational concepts and skills. The second variation is a depth-based development of programming skills through Scratch and web technologies, adapting several successful middle- and high-school courses. The third variation is a hybrid that punctuates skill-building in Scratch and web programming with curricular breaks contextualizing those skills. The project investigates how teachers and students respond to these different MyCS realizations. The project team will compare results within and among the primary partnering school district, Pomona Unified in Pomona, CA, along with our two secondary partnering districts, Lihue, HI and San Bernardino, CA. In order to maximize the number of students reached, the project focuses on middle-school teacher development through summer workshops and academic-year support.

Computation has become a crucial component of every modern endeavor. It has not, however, become a component of every modern student's identity. That is, the number of students who feel that "computation is something that people like me create" lags significantly behind the demand for computational creativity, both now and in the foreseeable future. Because of their pivotal role in early identity-formation, the middle-school years provide a window of opportunity to build a positive computational identity and to prime the pump for the ambitious CS10k project. To that end, this project develops, deploys, and assesses several variations of a middle-years computer-science curriculum, MyCS. The project team will build MyCS communities within targeted schools in three districts, each with a large majority of students from a distinct group underrepresented in STEM fields. Two key benefits will result. First, those communities will continue to develop computationally confident students even after the project concludes. Second, assessments will cull less effective variations and facets of MyCS, leaving a ready-to-go curriculum that will succeed in further regional deployment and will be prepared for larger-scale vetting, national trials, and broader adaptations.

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
Spanning 2013-2017, the MyCS project sought to design, deploy, and refine the U.S.'s middle-school computing curriculum. The project's primary aim was, for as many students as possible, to instill the belief that "people like me do CS." Although not every student believes this (yet!), the MyCS project significantly increased the positive computational identity of many "middle-years" students and sustainably increased the nation's capacity to foster such students in the future.

Short for "Middle-years Computer Science," MyCS is a curriculum seeded through private grants and sprouted through this NSF project. NSF funding made possible three crucial developments: (1) broader scope -- from a single district to many, (2) deeper data-collection, assessment, and evaluation, and (3) dissemination into both post-secondary academic venues and influential, sustaining K-12 host districts. We elaborate on each of these next.

(1: Broader scope)  The NSF MyCS project made possible 10 professional-development teacher workshops expanding MyCS's reach from a single district neighboring Claremont, CA into districts across the western U.S., including CA's Bay Area, Hawaii, and others around Los Angeles. Also, a 2016 seed workshop in New York City overlapped with that district's efforts to bring CS to all of its students. Over 200 teachers were reached through these workshops, and over 8,000 students have now taken MyCS per se or a MyCS'd course: flexibility of adaptation/adoption is both a hallmark and an essential facet of MyCS's successful reach.

(2: Deeper assessment)  The NSF project expanded our data-collection and curriculum refinement beyond teacher-participants to their students. Many thousands of student-surveys were obtained and analyzed. In broad strokes, the experience of MyCS does increase individuals' and the nation's identity- overlap with computing. Across diverse intersecting axes of identity, computing was shown as both welcome and complementary. The MyCS curriculum furthered precisely this mindset, providing a positive pathway to high-school computing, e.g., the new AP CS Principles course.

(3) The peer-reviewed publications at SIGCSE and CCSC (2013-2017) provide detailed breakdowns of the computational-identity questions and responses from many (sub)cohorts of students. Equally important, in 2015 the San Francisco Unified School District (SFUSD), as part of their curricular revisions to bring computing to all SFUSD students, chose MyCS as the cornerstone for that effort. After the 2016 pilot, every SFUSD middle school offers MyCS to its sixth-graders. The plan for 2017-2018 is that all district sixth graders will experience MyCS.

Yet more important than adopting MyCS has been SFUSD's meticulous adaptations of the curriculum. Now, what had begun as an academic thought- experiment has been tested by a diverse group of classroom teachers and has been field-iterated and -refined within one of the nation's most diverse student cohorts.

That the SFUSD version of the curriculum is now the "reference implementation" -- i.e., the starting point for other districts, nationwide, in providing computing curricula for their students -- testifies to the sustained returns the US will continue to draw from the NSF's investment in MyCS. 


Last Modified: 06/24/2017
Modified by: Zachary B Dodds

The project's primary aim was, for as many students as possible, to instill the belief that "people like me do CS."
